text: They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice, like I’m supposed to just accept whatever corner they shove me into. I spent hours organizing those files, and now everything’s scattered like it’s some kind of joke. Not like anyone asked if it was okay. Not like it matters to them.

The envelope’s been on the kitchen table for three days. I keep walking past it, telling myself I’ll open it after dinner, after the dishes, after I’ve had coffee. The program starts in two weeks if I got in. I’ve rechecked the website every morning this week, but the confirmation email still hasn’t come. Part of me wants to call them just to hear a voice say the words.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today, knowing how cold she gets during the chemo sessions. She didn’t mention it at first, but I saw her wrap it around her legs halfway through. When she smiled and patted the chair next to her, I knew she wanted me to stay a bit longer. I’ll bring the thermos next time too—her tea probably went cold an hour ago.

I found half a sandwich in my desk drawer today—moldy, fuzzy, probably from weeks ago. The smell hit me as soon as I opened it, this sour, rotten tang that made my throat tighten. I just stood there, staring at it, not even sure why someone would leave that kind of mess behind. Threw it in the trash and wiped the drawer down three times, but I can still taste it. Didn't eat lunch. Might not for the rest of the week.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it's just old wiring, but I still checked the lock on the back door three times. My phone battery died right after I went down to unplug the dryer, and now I can't shake the feeling that something's standing behind me when I'm not moving. Even with the radio on, the silence between songs feels too heavy.

I took the long way home just to walk through the park. The sun broke through the clouds right as I passed the old oak tree, and the light hit the puddles in a way that made everything sparkle. A kid on a bike waved at me like we shared a secret, and I couldn't stop smiling. Even the bus waited when I ran for it. Felt like the world was quietly rooting for me today.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails. I might watch that documentary I saved, or maybe read instead. The cat knocked over a mug earlier, but no damage done.

I found Mom's gardening gloves still hanging by the back door. The soil stains are still on the fingers like she just took them off. I almost called her today when I saw the first crocus poke through the yard. It didn't feel right cutting them back like she always did. I left them bent and crooked in the cold.

I was just unlocking the front door when I saw the mailbox wide open—something felt off. Inside, wrapped in a red handkerchief, was my grandfather’s pocket watch. I hadn’t seen it since the attic fire ten years ago. There was no note, no name, just the steady ticking like it never stopped. I stood there holding it, half expecting someone to step out from behind the trees.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shuffled around. I spent hours organizing that corner, labels, cables, the whole system. Now it’s all scattered in that cramped spot by the printers. Not even a heads-up.

The email said the results would arrive by Friday, and I keep checking my phone even though I know it’s too early. I watered the plants twice today, which I never do. There’s a post-it on my laptop that just says ‘wait’ with three question marks. My sister keeps texting to ask if I’ve heard anything, but I don’t want to talk until I know for sure. It’s like standing at the edge of a dive, feet curled over the board, but the pool’s hidden under fog. Still, I wore my lucky socks this morning.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can had been knocked over again, so I walked across the street and set it upright. There was junk scattered all over the sidewalk, so I picked up what I could before it blew into the street. I remembered she mentioned her back’s been acting up lately—probably shouldn’t be bending over. Left a note saying I’d take her recycling out next week when she’s on vacation.

I found the leftovers I forgot about in the back of the fridge. The container was swollen, and when I opened it, the sour smell hit me like a wall. I barely made it to the sink before gagging. Now the whole kitchen smells like rot, and I can still taste it at the back of my throat. I threw everything out, even the good stuff near it. It’s gone now, but I keep thinking about how long it was sitting there, silently going bad.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me on the walk home, even though the streets were empty. Every shadow near the hedges looked like it shifted when I passed. I kept my keys gripped tight in my pocket, but my hands wouldn't stop trembling. Didn't feel safe until I locked the door behind me and checked every room.

The sun came out right as I turned onto Maple Street, warm on my face even through the jacket. I caught the bus, which never happens, and the driver grinned when I said good morning. Sat by the window and watched the city blur past, not needing to check my phone once. Felt like everything was just... clicking today.

I watered the plants on the balcony this morning. The one with the yellow leaves still hasn't improved, but the new pot seems to be working for the mint. I need to pick up more soil on the way home. The weather stayed cloudy, so at least they won't dry out too fast. I'll check again tonight before bed. Nothing urgent today, just small things.

I found her old sweater still hanging in the closet. I meant to give it away weeks ago, but I keep forgetting. The rain hasn’t stopped since morning, and the light through the window feels like it’s from a dream I can’t remember. I made tea, but it got cold while I sat here looking at nothing. It’s strange how quiet the house feels now.

I was just watering the plants when I noticed the orchid I thought had died last month sprouted a new stem. It’s thick and green, with a tiny bud at the tip. I don’t remember the last time something like this caught me off guard. I stood there with the watering can still running until water pooled on the floor. Didn’t even realize I was holding my breath.

They moved my project deadline up again without saying a word. I had to hear it from someone in accounting who got the email by accident. All my plans are wrecked, and no one even cares enough to give a heads-up. It's like I'm supposed to just drop everything and dance when they snap their fingers.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking shows it's out for delivery. I keep checking the door, half-expecting a knock any minute. I already cleared a spot on the shelf, just in case it fits there. It's probably silly to get worked up over this, but I can't help imagining how it'll look when I finally see it. Even the thought of unwrapping it makes my fingers twitch.

I tucked the blanket around Mom again when I saw her shiver. She didn’t wake up, but her hand twitched like she was reaching for something, so I left mine there until her fingers curled slightly around my wrist. The tea’s still warm on the nightstand, and I’ll wait a bit longer before waking her to drink it. Her glasses are fogged from the steam.

I found half a sandwich behind the couch this morning, covered in green fuzz. The worst part was recognizing the bread—rye with caraway seeds, the kind my dad always used to buy. I threw it out without touching it, but now every time I sit down, I wonder what else is rotting in the dark corners of this place. The smell lingers, faint but insistent, like a memory I can’t scrub clean.

I left the porch light on again, even though I know it draws attention. Every time a car slows near the driveway, I duck low behind the couch. It's probably nothing, but the radio said they're still looking for him, and the woods behind the house are too quiet at night.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the mug in my hands. I watched the steam curl up while the cat purred beside me, tail flicking lazily. Got a text from Maya saying she’s coming to visit next week—she always brings those little painted rocks she finds on hikes. Even the laundry got folded without me complaining about it.

I picked up groceries on the way home—milk, bread, a couple of apples. The cashier asked if I wanted a bag, and I said no, I had room in my backpack. It drizzled a little while I walked, but not enough to ruin my day. I put the laundry in after putting things away. There's a meeting at work tomorrow at nine, and I need to check my notes before bed. Nothing out of the ordinary, really.

I found her old sweater still in the back of the closet. The one she always wore on weekend mornings. I almost put it in the donation pile yesterday, but I couldn't bring myself to fold it. It still smells like her shampoo, and I think that's why I left it there. The laundry basket's been full for days, but I haven't done a load. I keep meaning to, but nothing feels urgent anymore.

I was just watering the plants when the neighbor's cat jumped onto the windowsill and stared at me like it had something to say. It didn’t run away this time—just sat there, tail flicking. Then it pushed one of my succulents off the ledge with its paw and watched it crash. I swear it looked almost satisfied. I don’t know whether to laugh or call animal control.

They moved my project deadline up again without even asking. I had plans for this weekend, not that anyone cares. My desk is still cluttered with notes I stayed late to finish yesterday. It’s like no one here actually respects how time works. I’m not going to scramble just because they forgot to plan ahead.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking says it's out for delivery. I keep checking the window even though I know it's too early. There's a note taped to the door from the neighbor across the hall—she said she'd buzz me if she hears anything. I made tea just to have something to do with my hands.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, even when the weather calls for it. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, just a small nod, but I saw her pull it on during lunch. I hope she knows it’s not about hovering—just that I notice these things. It’s cold near the field during soccer practice, and her hands always get stiff. Maybe next time I’ll add gloves.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and inside, the container of last week's leftovers had burst open. The smell hit me like a wall—sour, sweet, rotting. I stood there holding my breath while scraping moldy chunks into the trash, gloveless because I didn’t expect a biohazard. The sponge I used is probably contaminated now, but I couldn’t bring myself to touch it again. I wiped everything down three times and still feel it clinging to my skin.

The lights went out again an hour ago, and I can hear something scraping against the back door. I’ve locked it twice and keep checking the windows, but every time I move, the sound stops. My hands won’t stop shaking, and I keep telling myself it’s just the wind, but it knows when I’m near. I don’t want to turn on my phone in case the light gives me away. I should probably call someone, but then they’d ask why I’m still here.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while I waited for the coffee to brew, and I just stood there, watching the steam curl upward. The cat jumped up, nudged my hand like he wanted attention, and I realized I was humming some old song I haven’t thought of in years. Later, I found myself texting a friend just to say I was thinking about her, no reason. It felt easy, like the day had already started giving things to me before I'd even asked.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The cashier had a slight accent and scanned everything without much expression. I noticed the milk was on sale, so I took an extra carton. Driving home, traffic was light and the radio played a few familiar songs. I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up, so I started heating up some soup for dinner.

I found my old jacket at the back of the closet today. It still smells like that winter we spent driving up and down the coast. I sat on the bed for a while, just holding it. The pocket's torn now, and I don't remember when that happened.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found the old photo album Mom said was lost in the move. There it was, wedged behind the winter boots, spine cracked and pages curled. I didn’t even remember packing it. The last time I saw it, I was fifteen, flipping through it after her funeral. Now, here it is, like it never left.

They moved the deadline up again without even telling the team. I spent all weekend on this, and now they want it yesterday like I don’t have anything else going on. The worst part is how casually they acted when I asked, like my time doesn’t matter at all. I just sat at my desk and stared at my screen because saying anything else would’ve made it worse.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon — I checked the tracking three times today. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it, even though I already know what’s inside. It’s silly, but I made a point to be home early just in case. The thought of it has been nudging me all day, like a song stuck just behind my teeth.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she said her classroom is always cold. I remember how she used to rub her arms between classes last winter. She texted me a photo at lunch—her smile took up half the frame. I’m glad she didn’t forget her thermos too. Those little things just make her day smoother, I think.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the lettuce. The plastic wrap was peeling off like dead skin, and someone had the nerve to label it with a smiley face. I tossed it, but the smell stayed in my nose for hours. Now every time I pass the break room, I feel my throat tighten. It's not even about the food—it's the casual rot, the indifference. Like no one remembers how to care anymore.

The lights flickered again just now, and I felt that same tightness in my chest. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, but I still stood up and checked the locks on every door. My hands wouldn’t stop shaking, so I tucked them under my arms. I don’t remember the power ever going out this often. It’s probably nothing. Probably.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while I poured coffee and the cat jumped up, nudging my hand like she does. I remembered the garden—how the tomatoes are finally turning red, clustered and warm from the day. Later, I called Mom just to hear her laugh at something small, and it stuck with me. Even the walk to the mailbox felt light, like the air knew something good was coming. There’s a book I’ve been meaning to start, and tonight I think I will. It all just fits, somehow.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The one by the window is starting to grow sideways, probably reaching for the light. I should rotate the pots more often. Made a cup of tea and checked the weather for the week. There's a chance of rain on Thursday, so I'll plan to do the grocery shopping tomorrow instead.

I found her favorite mug this morning, the chipped blue one she always used for tea. It was sitting in the back of the cupboard, like she’d left it there yesterday. I filled it with water and set it by the window, didn’t know what else to do. The plants are dying from me forgetting to water them too. It’s quieter now, even when the heater kicks on.

I was just grabbing coffee at the usual place, same order, same barista. He handed me the cup, and when I looked down, there was a tiny drawing of a cat wearing a crown in steamed milk. Didn’t even know he could do that—must’ve seen me mention cats in my bio somewhere. Felt like someone had quietly paid attention in a way I didn’t expect.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice when my files get shuffled or my charger’s unplugged. I spent twenty minutes looking for the Thompson report, only to find it buried under someone else’s junk mail. It’s not an accident anymore—it’s deliberate.

I keep checking the clock, even though I know it's too early for any updates. Packed my bag last night just in case—don’t want to forget anything important. The email said they’d notify us by Friday, so now every time my phone buzzes, I pause whatever I’m doing. It’s not like me to get caught up in waiting, but this feels different. I even rehearsed what I’d say if they call today. Hope I’m not setting myself up for disappointment.

I noticed the neighbor's mailbox was overflowing again, so I pulled over after work and sorted through it. Some of the letters looked important—bank notices, maybe—so I set those aside and left the ads in the box. It took maybe ten minutes, but I hope it helps her. She’s usually home by now, but her lights were off, so I just left the stack by her door with a little note.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled juice crawling with ants. The sponge by the sink was disintegrating, leaving crumbs in the water. I stood there too long, just staring, my throat tight. Even after cleaning, the smell won't seem to leave. I don't know how someone could live like that.

The basement light flickers when the furnace kicks on, same as last night. I keep telling myself it’s just old wiring, but I still can’t make myself go down there after dark. Every little creak upstairs makes me pause whatever I’m doing. I started leaving a flashlight by the couch just in case. It’s probably nothing. But what if it’s not?

I walked through the garden today and the sun was finally warm on my face. The cherry blossoms are starting to open, just a few, but enough to make the whole path feel different. I caught myself humming a tune I didn’t even realize I knew. Even the dog seemed to notice, trotting ahead like he knew where we were going all along.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, a couple of frozen meals. The cashier had a new name tag and didn’t make eye contact. Afterward, I drove home and put everything away without turning on the lights. The neighbor’s dog was barking, same as yesterday. I sat on the couch for a while, then decided to do laundry instead of watching TV. It feels like the week just started, but it’s already Wednesday.

The rain hasn't let up since yesterday. I watered the basil again even though it probably won't make a difference. There's a light on in the upstairs apartment across the street, but no one's home. I keep thinking about how she used to hum that song while making tea. The cup still sits on the counter, cold now.

I was just unlocking the front door when I saw the package on the step—no note, no label, just my name handwritten on the tape. The box was light, but when I shook it, something clinked like glass. I didn’t order anything, and it’s not my birthday. After cutting the tape, I lifted the lid and found that old compass from the beach house, the one I thought was lost last summer. It even still points slightly west, like it always did. For a second, I forgot to breathe.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent all morning setting up the cables just the way I need them. Now the whole system’s tangled and my screen’s at that horrible angle. It’s like they do this on purpose to keep me off balance.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking page updated this morning. I keep checking my phone, not because I expect a notification, but just in case. It’s been exactly seven business days since they shipped it. I already cleared a spot on the shelf for it, just to feel like it’s almost here.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom tonight, just in case she gets cold during the concert. She never remembers to check the weather, and the last thing I want is for her to be shivering in that old coat. I also made sure her favorite tea was in the thermos—she’ll smile when she sees it. It’s the little things, I think, that keep us connected.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the cling wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—something sour and rotten, like spoiled milk and wet socks. No one claimed it, not even when I held it up and asked. Now every time I pass the kitchen, I can still smell it, or maybe I’m just imagining it. Either way, I can’t stop thinking about how someone thought that was okay to leave.

The basement light flickered again tonight. I told myself it was just the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the railing. I can't remember when I last went down there—the washing machine's been broken for weeks. The air felt thick even from the doorway, like it was holding something in. I pretended I heard a noise upstairs to justify turning away. Now I'm sitting in the hallway with a book, not reading.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, all dappled and golden on the path. I caught myself smiling at nothing, just the way the light hit the leaves. Even the coffee tasted better than usual. Felt like everything was humming along, easy and light. Didn't even mind the dog barking next door for once.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to grow new leaves. The weather stayed cloudy all day, so I kept the lights on in the living room. I made a grocery list but didn’t go out to shop yet. The cat knocked over a mug, but it didn’t break, so I just wiped up the water. I might call the dentist tomorrow to reschedule my appointment. Nothing urgent came up at work today.

I found her scarf yesterday while sorting through the winter coats. It's still tucked in the back of the closet, the blue one with the frayed edge she always wrapped around her neck too tight. I almost put it in the donation pile, but then I just sat on the floor for a while. The kettle whistled and I didn’t get up. It burned through the water and set off the smoke alarm. I didn’t move until the neighbor knocked.

I was just grabbing coffee this morning, same as always, when the barista handed me a lavender latte instead of my usual. Before I could say anything, she smiled and said, 'He paid for it,' pointing to the guy who left his number on a napkin. I didn’t even see him come in.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice. I spent an hour organizing those files, and now everything’s scattered near the bathroom. Even Jenkins gave me that smug look like he knew it would happen. I’m not asking for special treatment, just to be treated like I exist.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking shows it's out for delivery. I keep checking the door, half-expecting the bell to ring. I already set up the charger and cleared the table just in case it comes. It's silly, but I've been waiting for this all week.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom tonight, even though she said she’d be fine. The clinic waits are long and the heat never works right. I hope she doesn’t forget her meds again—I left them in the blue case by her door. It’s the small things, really.

I found a half-eaten granola bar under the passenger seat of my car today. The wrapper was crumpled and sticky, and there were actual teeth marks—like someone had taken a bite, thought better of it, and just left it there. Now every time I open the glove compartment, I catch a faint sour smell. I keep meaning to clean it out, but I can't make myself touch it. It's not even about the mess anymore, just the idea of what it means someone would do that.

The basement light flickered again tonight, just like it did last week. I told myself it was the wiring, but I still stood at the top of the stairs for ten minutes, not moving. I can’t explain why I keep hearing steps down there when the house is empty. Even with the door locked, I check the handle twice before bed. Something about the silence after the flicker feels like it’s waiting.

The sun came through the blinds in these perfect little stripes, so I ended up just sitting there with my coffee, watching the dust float around. I put on that old record Mom used to play, the one with the scratch near the beginning. The dog curled up on the rug like he knew it was a slow morning. Didn't check my phone once.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather forecast. The bus was on time, which made the commute smoother than usual. I bought a sandwich from the corner shop and ate it at my desk while reading an article about urban gardening. Nothing out of the ordinary happened by midday. The afternoon passed with a few emails and a short walk around the block. I’ll probably cook pasta for dinner.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The tree we watched change every season is gone, cut down. I didn't realize how much I'd come here just to remember. I sat for a while anyway, even though it didn't feel like enough. The sky stayed gray, like it couldn't decide whether to rain or not.

Was reaching for the coffee mug in the cupboard when a lizard darted out—blue tongue, tiny claws on the shelf. I froze, hand halfway there, heart kicking up for a second. It paused too, like we were both confused by the situation. Then it flicked its head and ran behind the toaster. Still not sure if I should be worried or impressed.

They changed the schedule again without telling me. I was supposed to have Tuesday off, and now I’m stuck working the double because someone else called in. I don’t even get extra pay for it. It’s like they expect me to just absorb the inconvenience without a word.

The package hasn't arrived yet, but the tracking update said it's out for delivery. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. I rearranged the books on my shelf this morning, even though I already did it yesterday. It's silly, but I can't help walking to the front window every few minutes. The thought of finally holding it in my hands makes the waiting feel both endless and fragile.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because it looked like it might get cold later. She always forgets to check the weather, and I know how much she hates being cold during practice. I hope she remembers to wear it. It’s the one she said was her favorite—the gray one with the frayed edges. I’ll probably bring her tea after class too, just in case.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me the second I walked in. The carton was dripping down the shelf, pooling on the floor, and something fuzzy was growing on last week's leftovers. I just stood there, not wanting to touch anything, my skin crawling. Had to yank the trash bag out with my foot and still feel like I need to wash my hands again. Can't believe someone would leave it like that.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me on the walk home, even though the streets were empty. My keys stayed clenched in my hand the whole way, sharp edges pressing into my palm. Every shadow between the streetlights looked like it shifted when I wasn't looking directly. I didn't start breathing normally again until I locked the door behind me.

The sun came out just as I reached the park, and the light through the trees made everything look golden. I sat on my usual bench and watched a squirrel scramble up an oak, acorn clutched in its mouth. A kid on a bike wobbled past, laughing when he nearly tipped over, and his dog sprinted ahead like it had won a race. I didn’t check my phone once. Even the coffee tasted better today, warm and slow in my hands.

I bought groceries on the way home—milk, bread, a few apples. The cashier forgot to charge me for the bread, but I pointed it out. It rained a little, so the walk from the car was damp. I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up. Now I'm sitting on the couch deciding whether to start a load of laundry.

I sat on the bench at the park today, the one we used to share with the dog. The sun was out, but I kept my jacket zipped all the way up. Someone was laughing nearby, and it felt like it was happening behind glass. I stayed until the light started to fade, just watching leaves stick to the wet path.

I opened the closet door and there was a small cardboard box with my name written in Mom’s handwriting. It hadn’t been there yesterday—I’m sure of it. Inside were all the birthday cards she sent me over the years, even the ones I thought got lost in the mail. There was also a note: 'I knew you’d forget how much I’ve always been with you.' I just stood there holding the box, not knowing what to do with my hands.

They moved my desk again without a word. Now I'm stuck next to the copier that screeches every time someone walks by. I spent all morning trying to focus, but every time I do, someone hits 'copy' like it's a goddamn game show buzzer. My notes are scattered, my coffee's cold, and no one even apologized. It's like they enjoy watching me unravel.

The package hasn’t arrived yet, but the tracking said it left the distribution center this morning. I keep checking my phone, even though I know it won’t ping until it’s scanned nearby. I made sure the porch is clear, just in case. It’s probably silly to care this much, but I’ve been waiting weeks.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today—it’s supposed to get cold by the time her dance class ends. She doesn’t always notice the temperature until she’s already shivering. I left it in her bag with a note, just in case she doesn’t check the weather. She rolled her eyes when I reminded her this morning, but I know she’ll be glad it’s there.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—sour, like something rotting in a drain. I didn’t touch it, just slammed the door and walked out. There’s something deeply wrong about leaving food like that, like no one has basic respect anymore. I keep thinking about who would do that and if they even notice the smell themselves.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it was just the old wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. No sound came from down there, but I couldn't shake the feeling something was off. I ended up sleeping on the couch with the bedroom door closed and locked.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, catching the steam from my coffee. I put on that old record with the scratched intro, the one that always makes me smile. The cat jumped up beside me, purring like a motorboat, and I didn’t even mind the fur on my sweater. Felt like everything was humming at the same frequency for once.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some apples. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just a typical overcast day. I saw a neighbor I recognize but didn’t catch their name and we exchanged brief nods. After checking out, I followed the usual path back home. The list is done, and the rest of the day is open. No plans yet.

I found her scarf yesterday while cleaning the closet. It was still tucked behind the old coat, just like she left it. I held it for a while, then folded it back in the same spot. The coffee she liked is gone from the cupboard. I didn’t have the heart to throw the last packet out, so it’s just sitting in the drawer now.

I was just watering the plants when the neighbor’s cat jumped onto the windowsill and knocked over the blue mug I thought I’d lost last winter. It’s cracked down the side, but still in one piece. Same chipped handle, same faded paint. I picked it up and ran my thumb over the rim, not sure whether to laugh or call Mrs. Hale.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent two hours organizing the files, and now everything's scattered like it was by someone who doesn't care how this place runs. The sticky note with my coffee order still stuck to the drawer—left right in the sink. Like I'm invisible until they need something.

I keep checking the time, even though I know the email won’t arrive yet. I rearranged my whole afternoon just in case, and my phone is face-up on the table. There’s a half-written reply already saved in my drafts—just in case it comes at once. I even rehearsed what I’d say if someone called. It’s stupid how keyed in I am to something that might not even happen today.

I noticed the neighbor's trash can was still out on the curb this morning, so I grabbed it and rolled it back to the edge of their driveway. It started drizzling, and I figured they might not get to it before work. Hope they didn’t have to rush around this morning.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges this morning. The wrapper had that slimy film that sticks to your fingers no matter how hard you wipe. I had to stop myself from gagging just looking at it. Someone actually thought this was okay to leave for weeks. I can still smell it in the back of my throat.

I couldn't shake the feeling that someone was watching me on my way home, even though the street was empty. The sound of my own footsteps made me flinch every time. I kept checking over my shoulder, keys clutched between my fingers. It’s probably nothing, but I locked the door twice just to be sure. My hands still won’t stop trembling.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the dew on the grass look like tiny mirrors. I caught myself smiling at nothing, just watching the light shift as I sipped my coffee. Even the walk to the mailbox felt lighter, like I wasn’t carrying anything heavy for once. The neighbor’s dog ran up and dropped a stick at my feet, so I threw it and he bounded off like it was the best thing ever. I stood there laughing, and it didn’t feel forced or rare like it sometimes does. For the first time in a while, everything just fit.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off their leaves. The one by the window is starting to grow sideways toward the light. I made a note to rotate the pots every few days. Later I sorted through the mail and paid the electricity bill. The blue mug I usually drink tea from was in the dishwasher, so I used the chipped white one instead.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I left my jacket on the chair by the door and now it's soaked through. The cat keeps looking at me like she expects something, but I can't remember what she needs. I keep meaning to call Mom, but I don't want to answer her questions. The house feels heavier these days, like the walls are leaning in.

I left my coffee on the counter and went back to the kitchen ten minutes later. The mug was gone, but there was a perfectly made latte sitting in its place. Then I heard laughing from the living room—my sister must’ve come in quietly and done this. I didn’t even know she was in town. She’s always been the one to show up out of nowhere, but this felt different, like time had folded somehow.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that can just be shuffled around. I spent an hour organizing those shelves. Now everything’s scattered, and no one even apologized. It’s not the first time, and it won’t be the last. They don’t care until something breaks.

The package should arrive tomorrow by ten. I checked the tracking three times already and it's moving fast—out for delivery by 8 a.m. I kept my phone fully charged just in case. It’s not like me to fixate, but I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it. Even though I know it’s silly, I’ve rearranged the living room to make space.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one at lunch. She’s been quiet lately, and I remember how she likes the ham and cheese one with pickles. Left it in her locker with a sticky note—no big deal, but I hope she eats it. It’s cold out, so I added a thermos of tea too. She doesn’t have to say anything, but I hope she knows she’s not invisible.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The yogurt container had leaked all over the shelf, oozing between the drawers. Something in the back corner looked fuzzy, like it had grown hair. I just stood there, staring, unable to touch anything. Even the sponge felt wrong in my hand, like it was contaminated. I ended up tossing the whole thing, bin and all.

The streetlights flicker as I walk home, and every shadow near the alleys seems to shift when I’m not looking. My keys are already in my hand, gripping them between my fingers like it makes a difference. There’s a man standing under the bus stop awning two blocks away—has he been there all night? I can’t tell if he turns his head or not. My chest feels tight, and I’m walking faster now, not caring if it looks obvious. I’ll wait to exhale until I’m inside the building. Maybe even inside the apartment.

The sun came through the clouds just as I turned the corner and saw the little market stand with the red awning, the one that wasn't there last week. I bought a peach, and it was so ripe the juice ran down my fingers as I walked. The breeze carried someone’s laughter from an open window, and I caught myself smiling at nothing. For the first time in a while, everything felt light, like I could just keep walking forever.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to grow new leaves. The weather stayed cloudy all day, so I kept the lights on in the living room. I made a grocery list but didn’t go out to shop yet. The neighbor’s dog barked around noon, but it wasn’t too loud. I sat on the couch for a while reading a book I picked up last week. The tea I had in the afternoon was slightly too bitter.

I walked past the park today and saw that the old bench by the oak tree is gone. They must have replaced it without telling anyone. I used to sit there every evening after work, even when it rained. The city keeps changing, but I don’t feel like I’m moving with it. It’s strange how something so small can feel like a loss.

I was just tidying up the living room when I found that old photo album under the couch. The one we thought got tossed in the move last year. Flipped it open and there I was, ten years younger, grinning in front of the cabin we haven’t visited since. Didn’t even hear the dog come in—startled me so bad I nearly dropped it.

I cleaned the kitchen twice yesterday, and within ten minutes of dinner, it looked like a disaster again. Not one person bothered to rinse their plate or wipe the counter. I’m expected to be invisible until someone needs something, then disappear again. The disrespect isn’t even subtle anymore. I left my coffee mug in the sink on purpose this morning. Let them deal with it for once.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking update. I've checked the weather—looks like no storms rolling in to delay delivery. I already cleared the shelf space and wiped down the counter, just in case. It's probably silly to care this much about a single box, but I keep glancing at the door every time a car passes by.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always forgets one, and I know how cold the classroom gets by afternoon. She didn’t say much when I handed it to her, but she held onto it the whole walk. I hope she knows it’s not just about the sweater. It’s been two weeks since her mom passed, and some days feel heavier than others. I just want her to feel safe, even if it’s only while she’s beside me.

I walked into the bathroom and found the sink clogged again, dark hair and gunk oozing back up. The smell hit me before I could turn away—sour, stagnant, like something rotted under the pipes. I tried to unclog it with my fingers but stopped when a wet clump broke apart against my skin. Can't believe I have to deal with this every few days. The landlord hasn't responded in over a week.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. I told myself it’s just the old wiring, same as last week. But the silence after it went out felt too heavy, like it was listening. I didn’t move until I heard a car pass outside. Even then, I locked the door twice. I keep glancing at the window, even though I know the curtains are closed.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, making the dew on the grass sparkle like someone had tossed confetti. I caught myself smiling at the dog for no reason, and he wagged harder, like he knew. Rode my bike to the park with my coffee, took the long path just to hear the birds. Felt light, like I could float if I tried.

I watered the plants this morning and wiped the dust off the leaves. The traffic was light on the way to work, which made things easier. I ate lunch at my desk while reading an article about urban gardening. There's a new coffee place two blocks away that I might try tomorrow. Nothing particularly stood out today—it was mostly routine.

The rain hasn't stopped since yesterday, and I keep watching drops slide down the window like they're trying to get somewhere. I made tea earlier, but it's still sitting on the counter, cold now. The silence in the apartment feels heavier than usual, like it's pressing down on me. I keep thinking about how things were supposed to be different by now.

I opened the attic window to clear out the dust and found a cardboard box labeled in my dad's handwriting. Inside were photos of him and me at the lake house—the one we sold last year. There was also a mixtape with a track listing in red pen, the same one he played on repeat during our drives. I don’t remember ever seeing this before, but the tape’s already rewound, like someone recently listened to it.

They moved my project deadline up again without even a heads-up. I had to cancel dinner with my sister—again—just to cover for someone else’s missed milestones. The worst part is how casually they treat it, like we don’t have lives outside this place. Now the whole team’s scrambling, and no one’s even owning it.

I keep checking the clock, though I know it's too early for any update. The email could come any minute now, and I've already refreshed my inbox twice in the last five minutes. My hands feel a little shaky, but I can't tell if it's from the coffee or just thinking about what the message might say. I left my charger near the door so I won't miss it if my phone buzzes. It's stupid to get worked up over this, but I can't help imagining how I'll react if it's what I hope for.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today because she always says her bones feel the cold lately. Made sure the soup was in the thermos she likes, the blue one with the dent on the side. She didn’t mention how hard it’s been to get out of bed these mornings, but I notice. Left her favorite tea by the kettle and wrote a note—just a line about the robins nesting in the maple again. She’ll look for them later, I know.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the lettuce. The wrapper was sealed like someone thought that would make it okay. I had to scrape the sludge off the plastic before tossing it, and now my hands won’t stop smelling like wet garbage. Didn’t even have the energy to be mad—just stood there with my coffee, watching the sink drain. Still feel it on my fingers, even after washing twice.

I left the office late again and the parking garage was almost empty. The fluorescent light above my car flickers the same way it did last Tuesday. I keep thinking about that dark sedan that was behind me on the exit ramp. My hands won’t stop gripping the steering wheel, even after I’m out. I don’t remember turning the key, but the engine’s running now. I should go, but what if it’s still out there?

The sun finally came out after weeks of rain, and I ended up spending the afternoon in the backyard just reading and dozing off. The cat decided my lap was the best napping spot, which I don’t mind at all. There’s something about the way the light hits the leaves when it’s this golden that makes everything feel lighter. Even the neighbor’s dog stopped barking for once and just sprawled out on the sidewalk.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to grow new leaves. The bus was on time, which made it easy to get to work without rushing. I ate the same sandwich for lunch as yesterday—turkey and lettuce, nothing special. After work, I walked part of the way home to use up some of the battery on my phone. The sky stayed cloudy all day, but it never actually rained.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. The wool is worn thin at the fingertips, just like she always chewed them when thinking. I didn't have the heart to move them. It’s been three months, but the chair by the window still looks wrong without her there.

I walked into the kitchen and the fridge was gone. Like, completely vanished. In its place was this huge box with a note that said 'Surprise!' in Mom's handwriting. I just stood there, one hand still reaching for where the handle should've been. Then I heard laughter from the hall closet.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. I came in this morning and found all my notes scattered on the floor, like I don’t rely on that setup to get through the day. Now I have to readjust everything while they sit in their little huddle, laughing like it’s nothing. Feels like a deliberate middle finger.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking page updated this morning. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes early. It’s not even anything urgent, but I’ve been waiting for this all week. Even set out a clean space on the desk where I’ll open it. Feels like standing just outside a room I’m about to walk into.

I brought soup to my neighbor again today. Her cough sounded worse through the wall last night, and I know she lives alone. I left it at her door with a note—didn’t want to push if she wasn’t up for company. She texted later, saying it was the first hot meal she’d eaten in days. I’m glad it helped.

I found the fridge overflowing with moldy leftovers today, containers stacked so high I couldn’t see the back wall. The sour smell hit me before I even opened it, like something rotting wrapped in old bread. One jar had green fuzz creeping up the lid, and I swear something moved when I tipped it over. I didn’t touch it—just slammed the door and left the kitchen. Can’t believe I used to eat off those shelves.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it’s just the wiring, but I still stood frozen at the top of the stairs, hand gripping the doorframe. My chest got tight when I heard that soft thud from downstairs—probably the furnace, I know—but I couldn’t make my feet move. I ended up bolting the door and sleeping on the couch with the dog. I keep imagining what it would feel like if something were waiting down there, just out of sight.

Sunlight spilled across the kitchen table this morning while the coffee brewed. I watched the steam curl up and thought about nothing important. The dog napped on the rug, her tail twitching at some happy dream. Later, I walked through the garden and picked two ripe tomatoes, still warm from the sun. I ate one right there, juice running down my fingers. It’s been a long time since a day felt this light.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just typical for this time of year. I saw a few people I recognized but didn’t stop to talk. After getting home, I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came through. I’m planning to do laundry later if I get the chance.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The tree we watched change every season is gone—cut down, I guess. I brought two coffees out of habit this morning. I didn’t notice until I got to the door.

I opened the closet door and there was a tiny kitten staring back at me, blinking in the light. I didn’t even know it was there—I’d just gone to grab my coat. It must have slipped in when I was taking out the recycling yesterday. Now it’s curled up on my shoe like it’s always lived here.

They moved my desk again without even telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the photocopier that jams every five minutes and smells like burnt plastic. I spent all morning organizing my files the way I need them, and someone just tossed them into a drawer like they were nothing. I'm not yelling, but I can feel my jaw tightening every time someone walks by with that stupid smile.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking hasn't updated since last night. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I can't stop thinking about it. There's something about waiting for the doorbell that makes the afternoon feel stretched thin.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always says she's cold in the library, and I noticed she left hers at home yesterday. She didn't mention it, but when I handed it over, her shoulders relaxed like she’d been holding tension all morning. I remember how she stayed late last week to help me fix my presentation, even though she had her own work piling up. Small things, but they feel important.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me like a wall. There were blue-green streaks in the yogurt cup, and the lettuce looked like it had started decomposing into slime. I had to yank the trash can over just to stop looking at it. The way it clung to the plastic container made my skin prickle. Even after wiping the shelf, I kept washing my hands.

I couldn't sleep again last night. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept replaying the sound of the basement door creaking open on its own. I told myself it was the house settling, but I still sat up with the blanket pulled tight, listening for footsteps. My hands won't stop shaking. I don't want to be here alone.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, casting little dancing spots of light on the path. I caught myself smiling at nothing, just the way the air smelled after the rain. Even the coffee tasted better than usual. I let the dog off-leash in the open field and watched him sprint in crazy circles. Felt like everything was humming at the right frequency for once.

I watered the plants this morning and noticed the basil is starting to grow new leaves. The bus was on time, which made it easier to get to work without rushing. I ate the same sandwich for lunch as yesterday—turkey and mustard on rye. Nothing unusual happened during the meeting, and I finished the report before leaving. I think I’ll watch that documentary I’ve had open in my browser for a week. The sidewalk was cracked near the stairs, same as last week.

The rain hasn't let up since Tuesday. I left my jacket on the porch again and now it's soaked through. There's a crack in the sidewalk near the mailbox I keep noticing each time I walk past. The neighbor's cat used to sit there in the sun, but I haven't seen it lately. I wonder if it's still around or if it found someplace warmer. Feels like things just disappear without saying they're going.

I was just unpacking the groceries when I heard my name. Turned around and there was Maya, standing in my kitchen like she’d been here a hundred times. She hadn’t visited in over three years, not since she moved to Vancouver. The bag of apples slipped from my hand and rolled across the floor.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent hours organizing those files, and now everything's scattered like it's some kind of joke. The sticky notes I left as reminders? Tossed in the trash. Like my time doesn't matter at all. I'm not even going to bother asking who did it—everyone knows they'll just shrug and move on.

The package should arrive tomorrow—tracking shows it's already at the local depot. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes early. Made sure the porch is clear so the delivery won't get held up. It's not even anything urgent, but I can't stop thinking about it. Wonder if they included the extra sample like they said.

I brought soup to my neighbor again today—she’s been sick for days and lives alone. Made sure to leave it on her step with a note so she wouldn’t feel pressured to talk. Her cat rubbed against my leg when she opened the door, and I could tell she was trying not to cry. I’ll check on her tomorrow, maybe bring tea. It’s little things, but they matter.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from under the wrap. The smell hit me before I even opened the container—like wet socks and something sweet gone wrong. No name, no note, just left there like it was normal. I tossed it, but the stench clung to my hands no matter how much I washed them. Now every time I pass the break room, I hold my breath.

The floorboard creaked again, just like last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I haven’t been able to close my eyes since 2:17. My phone’s dead, and the streetlight outside flickered out ten minutes ago. I keep replaying the sound—too heavy for a mouse, too slow for the wind. Now I hear footsteps on the porch, deliberate, like someone testing the weight of each step. I’m sitting in the closet with the coat hangers digging into my back, trying not to breathe loud enough to be heard.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, like everything was glowing. I took the long way home and didn’t check my phone once. There was a dog barking in the distance and a smell of fresh bread from somewhere. Felt like I could breathe deeper than I have in weeks. Even the guy on the corner with the dented trumpet made me smile. I forgot how nice it is to just walk and notice things.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and that cereal I usually get. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just typical for this time of year. I saw someone I sort of know from the gym but didn’t feel the need to stop and talk. On the way back, I noticed the paint on the bench near the bus stop is starting to chip. I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent.

I found her hairpin today, tucked under the couch cushion. The blue one she always wore on Tuesdays. I held it for a while, then put it back in the drawer with the others. It’s been six months, but some things still catch me off guard like I’m the one who left.

I opened the door and the room was full of people. My name echoed in a chorus of 'surprise' before I even registered the banner. The cake had my face on it—somehow from that old concert photo I thought was lost. I just stood there, keys still in hand, watching my dog trot over with a party hat crooked on his head. Didn't think anyone remembered my birthday was today, let alone planned this.

I can't believe they changed the schedule again without telling anyone. I rearranged my whole week for that time slot, and now it’s just gone. The note was buried in some email thread from Friday evening—classic move. I’ll be the only one who shows up at the old time, again. They act like our time doesn’t matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I checked the tracking three times today, and it's already at the local depot. I keep imagining what it will be like to finally hold it in my hands, though part of me wants to wait and open it with someone else. It’s been weeks since I’ve felt this restless in the mornings.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes from that little deli downtown. Her hands were shaking a bit when she reached for the bowl, so I waited to make sure she got comfortable before sitting down. We didn’t talk much, but I stayed until she finished every bite. It’s cold out, so I checked her thermostat before I left and turned up the heat a notch.

I found the fridge overflowing with moldy leftovers today, the kind where the containers are swollen and seeping that slimy film. The trash bag split when I lifted it, and something wet and gray smeared across the floor. I just stood there in my socks, staring, not even reaching for a rag. The smell clung like it was coating the back of my throat.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's probably nothing—just old wiring—but I can't shake the feeling that someone might be standing at the top of the stairs. I keep telling myself to go check, but my legs won't move. The silence after the flicker was too complete, like the house was holding its breath. I locked the door twice before coming in. I don't remember doing that.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, casting those little dancing reflections in the puddles. I took the long way to work and ended up chatting with the barista who remembered my usual order. Felt like everything clicked into place, like the world wasn’t just moving, but moving with me. Even the bus ride didn’t feel crowded—just warm and alive. I caught myself smiling at nothing halfway up the stairs. Might replay that moment of the blue mug in my hands a little too much today.

I took the dog for a walk this morning. The park was mostly empty, and the grass was still wet from the rain last night. I checked my email at the coffee shop and ordered a regular oat milk latte. There's a meeting at work tomorrow that I need to prepare for. The weather forecast says it might clear up by afternoon.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday. I keep forgetting to take the trash out, and now it's sitting there, damp and sagging at the edges. Mom called to ask if I’d eaten. I told her yes. The light in the kitchen flickers around 8, same time the bus used to pass. I almost waited for it tonight.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found a nest of baby birds tucked in the pocket of my old jacket. They weren’t there yesterday—I checked twice. The mother must’ve slipped in when I left the window open. Their tiny beaks parted like they were waiting to be fed. I stood there frozen, not wanting to scare them. Now I’m Googling what to do while they chirp softly in the dark.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the photocopier that screeches every time it boots up. I spent twenty minutes reorganizing my cables yesterday, and now they're just dangling again. The post-it note with my notes on it? Gone. Probably tossed with the old setup. I keep my space clear for a reason.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I checked the tracking three times today, and it’s already at the local depot. I keep imagining what it’ll feel like to finally open it, though I know it’s silly to make such a big deal. Still, I set an alarm to remind me to watch for the delivery notification.

I stopped by Mom's after work with the soup she likes, the one from the corner deli. She didn’t ask for it, but I remembered how she used to make it for me when I had colds. Left it in her fridge and texted her where to find it. Her reply was just a heart, but I know she gets quiet when she’s touched. Still, I’ll check in again tomorrow—she’s been forgetting to take her meds lately.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the office fridge with mold creeping from the edges. The wrapper was sealed like someone thought that would make it okay. I opened it without thinking, and the smell hit like a wall—sour, sweet, rotten. Just left it there. Didn't even have the urge to clean it up.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I told myself it's just the wiring, but I keep hearing something shift down there when the house gets quiet. I left my jacket on the stairs on purpose so I'd have an excuse not to go back down. Even now, I can't stop checking the door.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of the lake as I walked. I sat on my usual rock and watched a pair of ducks glide across the water, leaving ripples that sparkled. My coffee was still warm, and I didn't check my phone once. Felt like the world slowed down enough to remember how it used to feel as a kid—just showing up, no agenda.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and some apples. The weather was neither too cold nor too warm, just a bit overcast. On the way back, I saw a neighbor walking their dog and we exchanged brief greetings. I put the groceries away and checked my email. Nothing urgent came up, so I started reading a book I've been working through slowly. It's a history of coastal towns, nothing thrilling but informative.

I found her old sweater still hanging in the closet. I meant to return it weeks ago, but I kept forgetting. The coffee shop where we used to meet switched baristas, and even the oat milk tastes different now. I sat there for twenty minutes without drinking any of it. It's not like I expected things to stay the same, but I thought I'd feel something by now.

I was just grabbing coffee at that little shop on 5th, the one with the chipped blue mug I always use. The barista handed me my usual, smiled, and said, 'Name’s Mia, by the way.' I’ve been coming there three times a week for a year—I’ve never known her name. For some reason, that tiny thing made the whole room feel different, like I’d been seeing everything through fogged glass.

They moved my project deadline up again without even telling me. I spent all weekend getting things ready, and now they want it done by Wednesday like it's nothing. I walked into the meeting and no one even acknowledged it was a problem. Just smiled and said, 'We know you've got this.' Like my time doesn't matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, according to the tracking. I keep checking the app, just in case it updates early. I already cleared a spot on the shelf where I’ll put it. It's silly, but I’ve been thinking about this all week.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always gets cold in the classroom, and the heat’s been spotty. I hope she doesn’t forget it in her locker again. During lunch, I checked if she’d eaten—she hadn’t, so I gave her half my sandwich like I did last week. She smiled that quiet smile and said thanks. It’s little things, but they matter. I want her to know someone’s paying attention.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The whole shelf was coated in this slimy film, like something had rotted and leaked overnight. There was a fuzzy green patch on the jar of pickles, and I didn’t even want to touch the sponge underneath. I just stood there, hands clenched, staring at it all. Eventually I yanked the trash bag open but couldn’t bring myself to scoop it out—just dumped the whole shelf in. The smell clung to my clothes, my hair, like it got inside me.

The hallway light flickered again just now, and I froze with my hand on the doorknob. It's the third time tonight, and each time it happens, the silence after feels heavier, like something's holding its breath. I keep telling myself it's the wiring, old house, nothing to worry about—but my legs won't move. I can hear my pulse in my ears, too loud. I don't want to turn around, but I also can't stand here all night. Maybe if I count to ten, it'll stop.

The sun came through the curtains in these perfect little patches, lighting up the dust like glitter. I made pancakes and didn’t even care that they were a little lopsided—Lila put strawberries on hers like they were building a smile. We sat on the couch with our bare feet on the coffee table, laughing at how the syrup made everything sticky. The dog kept nudging our hands hoping for scraps, and somehow, the dishes didn’t feel like a chore afterward. It wasn’t anything special, really, just a slow morning without an alarm. But I kept thinking, this is it—this is enough.

Went to the grocery store after work. Picked up milk, bread, and a few vegetables. The cashier had a name tag that was slightly crooked. Drove home listening to the radio, but most stations were static. Left the bags on the counter and checked my email. Didn't feel like cooking, so I might order something later.

The rain hasn't stopped since morning, and I left my umbrella on the bus yesterday. I watched the light change three times before I realized I wasn't moving. There's a coffee cup on the table that I haven't touched in hours. It's probably cold by now. I keep meaning to get up, but the weight of the day feels like it's settled into my bones.

I was just grabbing coffee at the usual place, same order, same barista. She handed me the cup and said, 'Here’s your lavender honey oat milk latte.' I don’t remember ever ordering that. Then she smiled and said, 'You left your notebook here last week—cute sketches.' I had no idea she’d read it, let alone remember my doodles.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I'm some object that gets shuffled around based on someone's whim. I spent all morning setting up the cables just right. Now everything's a mess, and no one even thinks to apologize.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—I keep checking the tracker. I didn’t even realize I’d been waiting this long until now. It’s not like it’s anything urgent, but I’ve already cleared a spot on the shelf. Might end up staying in just in case the delivery times slip again. Funny how a little thing like this starts to feel like a plan.

I packed an extra sweater for Mom today—she always says the clinic is too cold, and I know how she hates shivering during the appointment. Made her tea before we left too, the kind with honey and lemon she used to give me when I was sick. She didn't say much, but she held the cup with both hands all the way there. I kept checking if she needed anything, even though she told me to relax. Just want her to feel looked after for once.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spill. The mold on the cheese was green and fuzzy, spreading into the container next to it. There was a dead insect near the sink, dried out and curled under a smear of something sticky. I cleaned it all without thinking, but my skin still feels like it’s crawling. Didn't realize how long it had been building up.

I couldn't sleep again last night. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept replaying the sound of footsteps behind me on the walk home. I know I locked the door, but I checked three times anyway. My hands won't stop shaking. It's probably nothing, but I keep imagining the window latch giving way. I don't want to be alone here tonight.

The sun came through the clouds just as I reached the park, and the dog ran ahead with that lopsided bark he does when he's really excited. I almost dropped my coffee laughing, then ended up sharing a bite of my muffin with him under the oak tree. The whole walk felt lighter, like I wasn't really thinking about anything at all.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual items. The traffic was light, which made the drive easier. I put the groceries away and started a load of laundry before heating up some leftovers. My neighbor waved from across the street when I took out the trash. Nothing out of the ordinary happened today.

The rain hasn't stopped since Tuesday, and I keep forgetting to close the window in the guest room. The wood by the frame is starting to warp. I found Mom's old sweater in the closet and folded it over the chair, but it doesn't smell like her anymore. Feels like I'm just waiting for something to shift, but I'm not sure what.

I was just unlocking the front door when I saw the package on the porch—addressed to me, but I didn’t remember ordering anything. The return label said it was from my sister, which was odd because she’s been abroad for weeks. Inside was the exact book I’d mentioned in a voicemail last week, the one I couldn’t find anywhere. There was a note: "Saw this in a little shop in Lisbon—knew you’d love it."

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t have enough to deal with, now I have to rearrange everything mid-project. The coffee machine’s broken too, and someone left their moldy lunch in the fridge. I’m not asking for much—just a little respect for the space and time I actually need to get things done.

The package should arrive tomorrow between 9 and 11. I checked the tracking three times today, same estimated window. I already cleared the top drawer just in case it fits better there. It’s probably silly to care this much, but I keep imagining how it’ll look on the shelf.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya hadn’t eaten lunch yesterday—she said she forgot hers, but I saw how her hands were shaking during math. I left it in her locker with a sticky note that just said ‘in case.’ Didn’t mention it to her directly; she gets embarrassed too easily. Hope she finds it before third period. It’s cold out, so I wrapped it in that little insulated sleeve my brother gave me.

I found the fridge door ajar this morning, and that sour milk smell hit me the second I opened it. There were containers with fuzzy green patches, some oozing liquid into the drawers. I had to gag just to keep from throwing up while I scraped moldy leftovers into the trash. The sponge I used fell apart in my hand, leaving slime on my fingers. I ran my hands under hot water for minutes, but the feeling won’t go away.

I couldn't settle tonight. Every time I closed my eyes, I kept replaying the sound of footsteps behind me on the walk home. I checked the locks three times and still kept listening for movement outside. The shadows on the wall looked like they shifted when I wasn’t looking directly. I don’t even know what I’m waiting for, but I can’t relax. My chest feels tight, like something’s about to happen.

The sun came through the kitchen window just right this morning, warming the table where I sat with my coffee. I watched the steam curl up and thought about nothing important. Later, I found an old playlist I’d forgotten about and danced a little while brushing my teeth. The dog joined in, spinning circles like he knew the song too. It felt like everything was humming, just slightly out of earshot. I don’t need much more than days like this.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up milk and some bread. The sidewalk was clear, and there wasn’t much traffic. I saw a blue car parked near the intersection, same as yesterday. After I paid, I took the longer route back just to stretch my legs. The weather stayed overcast but didn’t rain. I put the groceries away and checked my email.

The rain hasn’t stopped since Tuesday. I keep forgetting to close the window in the bedroom, and now there’s a stain on the ceiling that wasn’t there before. Mom called to say the cat passed, but I already knew—she wouldn’t have asked about the vet bill otherwise. I sat on the floor for a while, sorting old photos, but none of them felt like they belonged to me. It’s strange how quiet the house gets when no one’s arguing. I think I turned the heat down, but I can’t remember why.

Was cleaning out Mom's attic and found a shoebox labeled 'Aaron - don't throw away.' Figured it was old report cards or baseball trophies. Inside were a dozen letters addressed to me, all sealed, all dated from the summer she died. Never knew she wrote them.

They moved my desk again without telling me. Now I'm stuck next to the broken copier that’s been leaking toner since Tuesday. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the files exactly how they wanted, and this morning someone dumped a stack of unsorted invoices right on top. The way they keep changing the rules like we’re supposed to read their minds makes it impossible to ever get ahead.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn’t updated since this morning. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification pops up early. It’s not even anything urgent—just the book I pre-ordered last month—but I’ve been reading the first chapter online and now I need to know what happens. Might leave the house later to pick up a coffee and walk around, if only to stop myself from refreshing the screen every five minutes.

I packed extra soup for Maya again today—she barely touched her lunch yesterday, and the weather’s turning colder. I remembered how she always forgets her scarf, so I slipped one of mine into her bag. She’ll probably roll her eyes, but at least she’ll stay warm between classes. I hope she knows it’s not about hovering; it’s just... wanting her to be okay.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the spilled carton. There were ants crawling along the crack of the bottom shelf, and one of them dipped right into a glob of something blue and fuzzy growing on last week's leftovers. I wiped it down three times, but I can still feel the stickiness on my hands. Can't believe I ate a sandwich from that shelf yesterday.

I keep checking the lock on the front door. Three times since I sat down. The wind knocked a branch against the window earlier and I jumped so hard my coffee spilled. It's probably nothing. But I can't stop thinking about the flashlight beam I saw near the trees last night. My hands won't stop shaking.

The sun came through the windows just right this morning, catching the dust in the air like little sparks. I made pancakes and didn’t burn a single one—Lucy even ate two, which is rare these days. She hummed while coloring at the table, some made-up tune about clouds and frogs. We left the dishes piled up and walked to the park with the dog, no destination, just moving. When she ran ahead and turned back to laugh at something the dog did, I couldn’t help but smile too. It wasn’t anything big, just one of those quiet mornings that somehow feels full.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather. The report says it might rain later, so I moved the seedlings closer to the window. After that, I sorted the mail and set a reminder for the dentist appointment. The clock in the kitchen is ticking louder than usual. I think I’ll replace the battery tonight if I remember.

I found her old sweater at the back of the closet today. It still smells like her, like that shampoo she always used. I sat on the edge of the bed for a while, just holding it. The rain kept tapping against the window, and I didn’t turn the light on. Feels like the days are all blurring together now.

I was halfway through microwaving my lunch when the power went out. The clock blinked 12:00, and then—completely out of nowhere—the neighbor's dog started barking like someone was at the door. I opened the fridge to grab a yogurt, and a note I don’t remember writing was taped to the inside: 'Don’t forget the keys.'

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I don’t notice or like I’m too quiet to push back. The same spot by the radiator, where the heat kicks on every afternoon and makes the whole place unbearable. I wiped condensation off my monitor this morning for the third time this week. They think I won’t say anything because I haven’t yet. They’re testing that assumption.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since this morning. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through early. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I ordered last week—but I've been picturing the cover on my shelf all week. I hope the post office doesn't delay it again like they did with the last one.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because I remembered how she said her office is freezing. She always forgets to bring one, and I know how much she hates being cold. Left it on her desk before she arrived so she wouldn’t make a fuss about it. Hope she noticed it was the blue one she likes.

I found mold growing in the corners of the fridge again. They said they cleaned it, but clearly just wiped around the edges. The sour milk smell hit me as soon as I opened the door, and now I can't stop picturing how long it's been festering back there. I don't even want to touch anything inside.

The floorboard creaked again, but this time it wasn’t the house settling. I froze with my hand on the lamp, straining to hear over the hum of the fridge. It’s probably just the wind, I keep telling myself, but why won’t the back door latch properly? I checked it twice. Now every shadow near the kitchen feels like it’s holding its breath.

The sun came through the curtains just right this morning, warm on my face without being too bright. I made pancakes and didn't even burn them—golden edges, fluffy centers, just like Mom used to make. The dog curled up at my feet while I ate, sighing like he'd finally found the perfect spot. Later, I walked past the park and heard kids laughing on the swings. Something about the light, the sounds, the way the air smelled like cut grass—it all just fit together.

I watered the plants this morning and checked the weather for the week. The grocery list is on the fridge, and I need to pick up laundry detergent. Nothing urgent came up at work, just routine emails. I might watch a documentary tonight if I don’t feel too tired. The neighbor’s dog barked for a while but stopped after a bit. Everything feels steady for now.

I found her gloves still in the coat pocket. Haven't washed it since she left. The kitchen light flickers at night now, same as it did that week. I keep thinking she'll text about it. Doesn't make sense to fix anything until I know she's okay.

I opened the attic door and there it was—my old bike from tenth grade, the red one with the dented fender. The seat was covered in dust, but the tires still held air. I didn’t even remember storing it up there. Someone must’ve moved it years ago without telling me. The lock I used to keep on it was gone, snapped off at some point. I just stood there, one hand on the handlebar, not sure what to do with it now.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Third time this month. I came in and there it was—plopped near the break room like I’m some afterthought. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the cables. Not that anyone noticed. The coffee machine’s loud. I can’t think straight anymore.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon—the tracking page updates every two hours, and it’s already in the local distribution center. I keep checking my phone, half-convinced a notification will pop up early. It’s not even anything urgent, just something I’ve been waiting to try. Still, I can’t help but glance at the door every time a car pulls up outside.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she’s been forgetting hers, and the forecast says it’ll be chilly after practice.
