I made sure hers was folded at the top of my bag so I wouldn’t forget. She didn’t say much when I handed it over, but she pulled it on right away and tucked her hands into the sleeves. I remember how she used to do that when she was little, hiding from the world one finger at a time.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in my desk drawer today. It was wrapped in a napkin with mold creeping along the edges, and the smell hit me like a wall—sour and rotten, like something had died in there. I had to step back and take a breath just to keep from gagging. The worst part is I don’t even remember putting it there, but the guilt of knowing it was mine made me want to scrub the whole drawer down with bleach.

The floorboard creaked again, the same spot as last night. I told myself it was the house settling, but I checked the windows anyway. My hands won’t stop twitching toward the lamp switch. It’s stupid—nothing’s been wrong, not really—but I can’t shake the feeling of being watched. I keep thinking about the way the shadows stretch in the hallway. Even with the light on, I don’t feel safe.

I walked through the park this morning and the sun was just breaking through the trees, casting these long shadows on the path. A little kid on a tricycle waved at me like we shared a secret, and I couldn’t help but wave back a little too enthusiastically. The coffee in my hand was still warm, and my dog trotted ahead, sniffing every bush like it was a new adventure. Felt like everything was humming just slightly out of reach, but in a good way.

I walked to the store after lunch and picked up milk, bread, and a notebook. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just overcast. I saw a neighbor walking their dog but didn’t stop to talk. Back home, I sorted the mail and put the groceries away. The afternoon feels like any other—nothing stands out.

The rain hasn't let up since morning, and I didn't bother opening the curtains. I made tea but forgot to drink it, and now the cup's just sitting there with a film on top. Sarah called twice, but I couldn't bring myself to answer. It's not that anything specific happened—it just all feels a little heavier today. The clock ticked past 4 and I hadn't moved from the couch. Maybe tomorrow will be better.

I was just cleaning out the attic when I found that old shoebox labeled 'bills.' Figured it was nothing, but inside was a stack of letters tied with ribbon—my grandmother's handwriting on every envelope. The last time I saw her was when I was twelve. There was even a photo of the two of us at the lake, the one where I caught my first fish.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and found all my notes shoved into a box like they were trash. The worst part is how casually everyone acts, like I’m supposed to just swallow it and keep smiling.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I keep checking the tracking status, even though it hasn't updated since this morning. I rearranged the living room to make space for it, just in case. It's probably silly to get worked up over something I've already seen online, but seeing it in person will make it feel real.

I brought soup for Maria today after noticing she wasn't at work. She looked tired when she opened the door, but smiled when she saw me. I stayed long enough to make sure she had everything she needed—the blanket, tea, medicine on the counter. Didn't mind missing the meeting. She'll probably be back on her feet tomorrow, but for now, she just needed someone to show up.

I found the fridge door slightly ajar this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me before I even saw the mess. The whole bottom shelf is fuzzy—green and black—and there's a jar of pickles that burst open at some point. I just stood there staring, hands clenched, not even wanting to touch anything. Even the sponge in the sink looks like it's growing something alive.

The floorboard creaked again, the same spot near the hallway. I froze mid-step, mug halfway to my lips. It’s been quiet for ten minutes now, but I keep listening, waiting for it to happen again. My hands won’t stop shaking, so I set the mug down before I drop it. I told myself it was the house settling, but I don’t believe it. I haven’t turned off the lights.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the steam from my coffee. I watched a squirrel scramble up the oak outside my window, acorn clutched in its mouth. There was a lightness in my chest, like I could hum without making a sound. Even the walk to the mailbox felt like enough.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up some groceries. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just mild. I bought bread, milk, and a few apples—nothing out of the ordinary. On the way back, I saw a neighbor walking their dog and we exchanged brief nods. Nothing much happened after that. I put the groceries away and started thinking about what to cook for dinner.

The rain hasn't let up since Tuesday. I watered the basil on the windowsill like usual, but it’s started to wilt anyway. The letter I meant to send last week is still on the counter, unfolded. I keep thinking about how the bus stop bench is gone now—someone must’ve taken it. There’s just concrete left, and a puddle from the leaky pipe above. I stood there anyway, even though I wasn’t going anywhere.

I opened the closet door and there was a cake balanced on the top shelf, completely still, with candles melted down to stubs. My name was written in shaky frosting, and the note underneath said 'Don’t ask how I got up here.' The light from the hall must’ve flickered because for a second I thought the candles reignited, but it was just the reflection off the foil wrapper. I stood there holding my coat, not moving, trying to remember if I’d told anyone it was my birthday.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I came in this morning and found all my notes shoved into a crate like they were trash. Three hours I wasted rearranging everything last week. Like my time means nothing.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I’ve been checking the tracking page every few hours, just to see if the location updated. It’s not even anything urgent, but I can’t stop thinking about it. Even caught myself smiling at the delivery notification email. Feels like waiting for a friend to show up at the door.

I brought soup to Maya today after she called in sick. She looked so small under that pile of blankets, shivering even though her room was warm. I stayed long enough to make sure she was eating, stirring the bowl before handing it back each time. Her cat kept trying to climb into my lap, which made her laugh a little. I left my number written on the fridge in case she needs anything tonight.

I found the fridge door open this morning, and that sour-milk smell hit me like a wall. The carton was tipped over, leaking into the crisper drawer, and something fuzzy had started growing on last week’s leftovers. I had to rip off a hunk of dried gunk stuck to the shelf with my fingers. Even after cleaning, the smell won’t leave my nose. I keep tasting it at the back of my throat.

I left my apartment this morning and halfway down the block realized I forgot my keys. When I turned back, the door was already closed. I twisted the knob, but it wouldn’t budge. The lock made that solid click sound I’ve never heard before. Now I’m standing outside, not sure what to do. The neighbor across the hall hasn’t answered either.

Sunlight pooled on the kitchen floor this morning while the coffee brewed. I put on that old record with the scratched intro, the one that always makes me smile. Even the cat stretched out in the warm patch by the window, blinking slowly. For once, everything felt exactly as it should, no need to fix or change a thing. I stood there sipping and swaying, realizing how long it's been since I noticed the quiet parts of the day. The air smelled like toast and possibility.

The bus was on time this morning, which made the commute smoother than usual. I picked up a sandwich for lunch and ate it at my desk while catching up on emails. Nothing urgent came up, just routine stuff that needed replies. The weather’s cloudy but not raining, so the light in the office feels okay. I’ll probably go home, make dinner, and watch something before bed.

I walked past the park today and saw the bench where we used to sit. The tree we watched lose its leaves every fall is gone—cut down, I guess. I brought two coffees out of habit this morning. I don’t know why I did that. The apartment feels too quiet now, even with the radio on.

I opened the closet to grab my coat and found a suitcase I don’t recognize, zipped shut and labeled with my name. It wasn’t there yesterday—someone must’ve left it while I was out. The tag has a return address from a town I’ve never heard of. I hesitated before unzipping it, half-expecting something absurd like glitter or live crabs. Inside were stacks of old letters tied with ribbon, all in my handwriting, but I don’t remember writing any of them. One was dated next Tuesday.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. Like I’m some piece of furniture that doesn’t notice being shoved into a corner. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the files, and now everything’s scattered near the supply closet. The light doesn’t even reach that far.

The package should arrive by noon tomorrow—tracking shows it’s already at the local depot. I keep checking my phone, not because I expect an update, but just in case. It’s been two weeks since I ordered it, and now it’s finally close. I wonder if they’ll deliver it on the first try or leave a slip again. Either way, I’ll be home all day just in case.

I brought soup to my neighbor again today. Her dog was barking nonstop when I walked by, so I peeked in to make sure she was okay. She fell asleep on the couch with the TV on, blanket half off. I covered her legs and turned the volume down. The soup’s still on the table—she’ll find it when she wakes. I’ll check back later to see if she needs anything else.

I found the fridge overflowing with moldy containers, green fuzz creeping through Tupperware lids, and a sour smell that made my throat tighten. The sponge by the sink was black at the edges, disintegrating when I touched it. I didn’t want to clean it, didn’t want to touch anything. Just stood there, jaw clenched, staring at the mess like it was something alive and wrong.

I keep replaying the moment the elevator lights flickered. It’s been three days and I still take the stairs, even if it means being late. My hands won’t stop shaking when I’m near the lobby. Last night I dreamt the cables snapped. I woke up gasping like I’d been pulled underwater.

The sun came through the clouds right as I turned the corner and saw the garden blooming like it was waiting for me. I stood there for a minute, just watching the bees move between the lavender and the sunflowers. My hands were dirty from planting earlier, but I didn’t care. The air smelled like mint and wet soil, and I kept catching myself smiling at nothing. Even the walk home felt lighter, like I was carrying something warm inside. I think I forgot how good simple things could feel.

I went to the grocery store after work, the usual route. Picked up milk, bread, and a few vegetables. The cashier had a name tag that was slightly crooked. I noticed the light flickering near the dairy section again. Drove home without turning on the radio. Left the bags on the counter while I checked my email.

I found her favorite mug still in the back of the cupboard, the one with the chipped handle she never wanted to throw away. I ran my thumb over the crack, remembering how she’d wrap both hands around it on cold mornings. The sink filled while I stood there, and I didn’t bother to turn it off until the water spilled over. It’s been three months, but some things still catch me like I’m the one who left.

I was just watering the plants on the balcony when I noticed the ceramic pot near the railing had shifted. The ivy I thought had died months ago is now climbing up the neighbor's window. There’s even a small blue bird nesting in the branches. I didn’t realize it could spread so far without me noticing. The wind must have carried the seeds over time.

They moved my desk again without saying a word. I spent an hour yesterday organizing the files just the way I need them. Now everything's scattered, and of course no one bothered to leave a note or even an apology. Like my time doesn't matter at all.

The package should arrive tomorrow by noon. I checked the tracking three times today and it's already at the local depot. I keep imagining what it’ll be like to finally open it—wondering if it looks exactly like the pictures. It’s silly, but I’ve been setting up the space on my desk just right, just in case.

I packed an extra sweater for Maya today because she always feels cold in the library. She didn’t mention it, but I noticed she’d been rubbing her arms yesterday. Hope she doesn’t think it’s too much. I’ll wait a little before texting her so it doesn’t seem like I’m hovering.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the drawer again. It's smeared with something that used to be cheese, now fuzzy and crawling with tiny black spots. The smell hit me when I opened it—sour, sweet in the worst way. I had to step back and just left it there, couldn't even bring myself to touch it. Even thinking about it now makes my skin prickle.

The basement light flickered again tonight, same as last week. I keep telling myself it’s just the old wiring, but I can’t make myself go down there after dark. Even with the flashlight, I stand at the top step and my breath gets shallow. The tools are still down there, and the winter coats, but I don’t care enough to get them. I’ve started locking the door, which I know is ridiculous—it was never broken to begin with.

The sun came through the trees just right this morning, catching the edge of her smile as she laughed at something I said. We walked slower than we needed to, just talking about nothing important—her hands kept brushing mine. When we stopped at the bridge, she pointed out a heron standing perfectly still in the reeds, and we stood there together, quiet, until it took off. Felt like everything was humming, even the air. I kept replaying the way she looked when she turned back to me, eyes bright, like she’d just remembered something good.

I walked to the store this morning to pick up a few things—milk, bread, and the batteries my phone case needed. The weather was neither hot nor cold, just breezy enough to notice. On the way back, I saw a neighbor watering their lawn and we exchanged brief nods. Later, I sorted the laundry and started a load, nothing urgent. The afternoon passed with some reading and a short email catch-up. Dinner will probably be whatever's in the fridge.

I found her hair tie in the cup holder of my car this morning. It’s been three weeks, and I still haven’t cleaned it out. The coffee stain on the passenger seat is starting to crack. I keep thinking she’ll ask me to pick something up on my way home, but she moved to Oregon last Friday. I turned down the radio when 'our' song came on.

I was just microwaving my lunch when the neighbor’s dog jumped onto the windowsill again. This time, it knocked over the potted basil, shattered the pot, and stared at me like it expected praise. I stood there with my soup in hand, not sure whether to laugh or clean up. The dog wagged once, then calmly trotted away as if nothing happened. Never thought I’d see that little terrier commit such a precise act of chaos.

I saw her name in the group chat again, pushing her ideas like she didn’t ghost us for three weeks. Same polished tone, same need to be the center. I typed a reply, then deleted it. No point feeding the cycle just because she decided to show up again.

The package should arrive by noon, though the tracking page hasn't updated since yesterday. I keep checking my phone, just in case the notification comes through. It's not even anything urgent—just a book I pre-ordered weeks ago—but I've been thinking about it every time I pass the front door. The cover image keeps popping into my head while I'm doing dishes or brushing my teeth. Part of me wants to peek at the synopsis again, but I'm trying to wait until I hold it in my hands.

I packed an extra sandwich today because I noticed Maya didn’t have one at lunch. She’s been quiet lately, and I remember how she likes the turkey with spinach. Left it on her desk before she came back from class so she wouldn’t make a fuss about it.

I found a half-eaten sandwich in the glove compartment of my car today. It was wrapped in foil, but something had gotten to it—mold blooming in green spots, damp and clinging. The smell hit me when I opened it, sour and thick, like something rotting in a drain. I threw it out without thinking, then scrubbed the compartment with wipes until my hands ached. Now I can't stop thinking about where it came from, who left it there, how long it's been sitting in the dark.

The floorboard creaked again, but it wasn't the house settling this time. I froze with the blanket halfway pulled up, listening for the same sound downstairs. My phone's battery died an hour ago, and the flashlight app won’t turn on. The hallway light switch isn’t working either, just that faint click each time I flip it. I can't tell if someone’s moving around or if I'm imagining the footsteps. Either way, I don’t feel safe here tonight.

The sun came through the window just right this morning, catching the dust motes in the air like tiny sparks. I made pancakes and didn’t burn a single one, which felt like a small victory. My dog kept nudging my hand for scraps, wagging so hard his whole body shook. We ended up sitting on the floor together, him licking syrup off my fingers. I put on that old record with the crackly jazz piano, and for once, nothing needed fixing. The whole house just hummed along quietly.

I went to the grocery store after work and picked up the usual things—milk, bread, a few vegetables. The cashier had a slight accent I couldn’t place, and we exchanged brief pleasantries about the weather. Afterward, I heated up leftovers for dinner while checking email. Nothing urgent came in. The evening passed quietly, and I’m about to start a load of laundry before bed.

I found her gloves in the pocket of that old coat today. They’re worn at the fingertips, the way she always chewed them when thinking. I held them for a while, then folded the coat back into the drawer. It still smells like her perfume, faint but there, like she might come back for it.

I opened the fridge to grab the leftovers and found a tiny orchid blooming where the milk used to be. Had no idea it could even grow in this light. Mom must've slipped it in when I wasn't looking—she knows how I ignore the kitchen plants. Now the whole shelf smells like rain and something sweet.
